transcripts.text: We have seen a warming in our world like never before.  This town has seen three 500-year floods in just five years.  It is the threat to every living thing on this planet and we are running out of time.  We need courageous leadership.  We can get this done.

A lot of the candidates on the stage have said climate change is a priority.  And so what we want to see is what does that look like?  And how are you going to address the fact that the fossil fuel industry has bought our democracy in so many ways?

Hi, I'm one of the Greenpeace climbers under the Fred Hartman Bridge in Houston, Texas.  We are shutting down fossil fuel traffic in the Houston shipping channel.  This is the largest oil export channel in the country.  All of the major oil companies, Exxon, Shell, Chevron, they all depend on this terminal.
700,000 barrels of oil come through here every single day, but today not a single one came through.
We have now shut down all marine traffic up the Houston shipping channel.

We are here today to put a stop to the fossil fuel industry and the damage they are doing to our planet.  And we're here to also press our elected representatives, our next president, to push for a Green New Deal so that people working in the fossil fuel industry can get stable, high-paying jobs in renewable, clean energy.  So that's why we're here.  It's a little scary.  It's pretty exhilarating.

This is definitely the outside of my comfort zone.  But it is inherently risky to not deal with climate change.  We are in a crisis.  We are in an emergency.  And so we're not talking about just what's going to happen for future generations.  For people who are more marginalized, this is a reality.  We're already there.
We're taking bold action to inspire folks to join the movement.  There's many different ways to get involved.
We don't need everybody to do what we did today.  Whatever is in your toolbox, whatever step you have not yet taken, we need you to take that step.
And I hope you'll join us in the streets for the climate strikes on September 20th and 27th.  None of us are alone, and when we all speak up together, we can make these changes happen.
You can see very beautifully the sun is setting behind the oil refineries, like the age of oil is coming to an end.
So it's been a little over 12 hours and we're still here.  It's possible to imagine something different.
